content: The "FEMA Reauthorization Act of 2017" amends the Post-Katrina Emergency Management Reform Act to update funding for the Federal Emergency Management Agency for fiscal years 2018-2020. Additionally, it includes a provision for a comprehensive study of disaster costs and losses. The Administrator will conduct a comprehensive study on disaster costs and losses and Federal disaster assistance through the National Advisory Council. The study will include members with technical knowledge, insurance industry representatives, experts in construction, and individuals nominated by national organizations representing governments and personnel. The National Advisory Council for the comprehensive study on disaster costs and losses will include members from State, local, and tribal governments, academic experts, private industry representatives, and other relevant entities. The Council will also consult with federally funded research entities and academic institutions for research and innovative technologies. The National Advisory Council will evaluate disaster costs, losses, and Federal assistance within 120 days of the Act's enactment. This includes assessing trends and factors contributing to disaster costs, such as loss of life, property damage, and available Federal disaster assistance. The National Advisory Council will develop recommendations to reduce disaster costs and losses in the United States and improve the delivery of Federal disaster assistance. This includes enhancing national disaster assistance decision making, providing incentives to reduce costs and losses, and implementing mechanisms for cost and loss reduction. The National Advisory Council will develop recommendations for disaster cost reduction, mitigation, and resiliency. This includes legislative proposals for implementing recommendations, addressing challenges to implementation, and projecting dollar savings and efficiencies. The Council will submit a report to the Administrator and Congress within 1 year. The Administrator will make data collected publicly available on the Agency's website for the Committees on Transportation and Infrastructure and Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs. The National Domestic Preparedness Consortium funding is amended for fiscal years 2018-2020, with specific allocations for the Center for Domestic Preparedness and other members. Additionally, the year in subsection (e) is updated from 2007 to 2015. The Administrator of FEMA is responsible for national earthquake and tsunami preparation and response efforts to reduce loss of life and property. They develop plans to prepare, mitigate, respond to, recover from, and adapt to such events. The non-federally funded actions of private parties, State, local, or Tribal governments on various lands shall not be attributed to FEMA's actions under specific flood insurance acts for the purposes of the Endangered Species Act. The Insurance Reform Act of 2012 and the Homeowner Flood Insurance Affordability Act of 2014 do not create a Federal nexus for applying the requirements of the Endangered Species Act. SEC. 7.
